results.notes:
Code: Bot_781/2014_DSC9795

Habitat: steep mountain slope, south-southeast aspect, calcareous ground, open place, full sun, exposed to direct rain, average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5-6 deg C, elevations 830 m (2.700 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: cut down Fagus sylvatica trunk lying on ground, on bare wood.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, southeast slopes of Mt. Trentarski Pelc, 2.109 m (6.918 feet), next to the dirt road to Planina Vejerica, between eighth and ninth switchback of the road, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: First I thought I found some species of genus Hypoxylon. The problem was, as I wrongly thought, they grew exclusively on tree bark, not on wood directly (most frequently they do so, but not exclusively). Therefore I considered genus Kretzschmaria, possibly not yet mature and common Kretzschmaria deusta. I know bright whitish-gray anamorph of it and quite common mature completely black stroma. But I’ve never found something in between. Only after consulting AscoFrance, Mr. Enrique Rubio the pictures were determined as Annulohypoxylon cohaerens (former Hypoxylon cohaerens). Genus Annulohypoxylon was separated from genus Hypoxylon in 2005. Actually subglobose, somewhat flattened above, confluent, at first brown, stroma with papillate ostioles fit well to this determination although the fungus is not yet fully mature. This fungus is an inhabitant of beech and it appears on bare wood as well as on bark. It often grows together with similar Hypoxylon fragiforme, which is a very common species in our woods. Extraction of pigments by KOH and microscopy would make this determination crystal-clear. But this was not done. The discussion about this find on Asco France forum can be reached here: http://www.ascofrance.com/forum?page=1 (search for ‘Kretzschmaria deusta ?’).

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes: Found in a forest clearing on a rotting oak tree. There had been significant rainfall the preceding day, and temperatures had risen from highs in the low 60s to highs in the mid 70s, with humidity increasing significantly. I’d checked the spot a week earlier and hadn’t found anything. There were hundreds of them growing on the rotting wood, and most of them still had their white interior, with only a few exceptions. I picked the larger specimens and plan on cleaning them for the fridge tonight.

results.notes: Single basidiocarp growing on a hardwood log in a floodplain near Platanus occidentalis, Populus deltoides, Asimina triloba, Acer negundo, Aesculus flava and Ulmus sp. Cap changing from dark brown when fresh to bluish gray; 6.1 cm wide. Basidiocarp 5.3 cm tall. Stem and gills bruising slowly blue. Young gills white before changing to pink. Pileipellis a cutis with clamp connections between the hyphae. Pleurocystidia strongly hooked. This seemed unusually robust for P. americanus to me but it seems like a decent match microscopically.
results.location_name: Academy Park, Gahanna, Ohio, USA

results.notes:
this clearly underwent a serious transformation post-collection. The tackle-box is not air tight, but some specimens fair better than others. the timestamps on the field vs. studio images show a lapse of about 12.5 hours. I suspect that, as in the case of Observation 271251, the conditions in the box accelerated naturally occurring color changes, as opposed to producing new ones consistent with rot or suffocation. if that’s true, perhaps this is black staining (damn my lack of notes), and therefore maybe a member of section Compactae subsection Nigricantinae? or are there other black-staining groups within Russula?

results.notes:
(Local name: Валуй. It is a local copy of Almond-scented Russula).
Сap: 5-16cm rounded as a square head, expanding to convex or flat and slightly sunken in the centre when old; margins curved in and radial lined when old, young is slimy, than some tacky in wet weather, glossy and shiny in dry season; colour from yellowish-white or brownish-white up to yellowish-brown or brownish-yellow. Flesh is white up to light brown after some damage. Gills are attached, close and narrow when young than broad and almost distant; colour from white up to dull yellowish-white and brown coarse damage. Young unit has weak white acrid milk at gills.
Stalk: 3-8cm long, white up to dull yellowish-white or dull brownish-white; 1.5-4cm thick, usually slightly enlarging down than narrowing at the base, loose or hollow in the central part.
Habitat: common kind, scattered up to abundant or crowded in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
Edibility: good for long winter keeping (special methods of cooking using fermentation).
It is a copy of Russula laurocerasi Melz., according description.
Season: July – September.

Habitat: light wood, Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Juglans regia, Corylus avellana dominant; slightly inclined mountain slope, east-southeast aspect; calcareous, skeletal ground; mostly in shade, relatively warm place, partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 590 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: mostly vertical surface of calcareous rocks of a stony fence along the path; sometimes associated with mosses.

Place: Lower Trenta Valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, next to the path from Skokar farm house, Trenta 2 to cottage Trenta 2b, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: This find seems to fit well to the traits of (former) Collema crispum as described in Ref. 1 and 2. Morphological traits as well as substratum seem to be right. Also the picture published in Wirt (1995) (Ref.1), which is also cited as relevant in Smith et al. (2009) (Ref.2) shows great similarity with this find. The same seems to be true for the pictures published in Ref.5. The only objection may be, that in this find there are only a few flattened isidia seen. Apparently most of them are still young and hence +/- globose.

Collema crispum doesn’t seem to be a valid name any more. Recent molecular studies have changed taxonomy of jelly fungi (Collemataceae) drastically. The main morphological distinguishing trait between the largest and commonest genera Collema and Leptogium, that is thallus cortex character, is clearly proven not to be monophyletic. Phylogenetic molecular study (Otálora et al. 2013) (Ref.6) has been done (based on the best unconstrained trees), which resulted in some clades, for which there was no morphology supporting such a classification. In 2014 in order to reconcile morphology and molecular data, a new classification for Collemataceae was proposed (Ref.3). Based on slightly constrained topology ten clades were proposed. All of them can be characterized using a combination of traits as habitat preference, thallus habit, ascospore characteristics, thallus anatomical structure, and cortex.

Now, following Index Fungorum the name Collema crispum (Hudson) Weber ex Wigg. is a synonym. Corresponding current name is Blennothallia crispa (Huds.) Otálora, P.M. Jørg. & Wedin, Fungal Diversity 64: 282 (2014). According to the key published in Otálora et al. (2014) (Ref.3) genus Blennothallia should have thallus with partially paraplectenchymatous medulla (a fungal tissue consisting of more or less isodiametric, rounded to angular cells) and Nostoc photobiont in short chains with less than 3 cells. Both traits clearly do not correspond to my find. According to the key the observed non-paraplectenchymatous medulla and very long Nostoc chains speak in favor of (new) Collema or (new) Lathagrium genus. But Collema is now mainly a corticolous genus and my find is strictly saxicolous. Also in the list of species C. crispum doesn’t exist. Similarly in the (new) genus Lathagrium the name L. crispum does not exist. Also, for (new) genus Lathagrium very frequent apothecia are characteristic. But I haven’t found a single one on more than ten specimens carefully checked. Thus I don’t know how to properly name this find (even not to genus level). I will stay with old Collema crispum although it is possible that this find is not that or that I missed something in this complex naming issue? Any help or idea is very much welcome.

Thallus loosely attached to the rock by scattered whitish hapters; photographed in wet state after rainy days; isidiate; blackish-brown and fragile when dry. Thallus up to 20 × 5 cm large but usually much smaller; many (>20) specimens present all along the stony fence.

results.notes: Agaricus in mixed broadleaf woods, but closest to Coast Live Oak, which was the dominant tree there. Quite thick-stiped and stocky, with a club-shaped bulbous base. Cap was several cm across; not very big. Did not seem to bruise, but perhaps the mushroom was too old or the change was too slow. I felt that it had a “mealy” smell, but perhaps that would be considered “bread” or “almond” by some. I highly doubt this Agaricus is one of the phenol ones, though, and it would not be one of the cypress ones, either. The sole conifer around the location would be Gray (Foothill) Pine, which is unlikely to host an Agaricus. I have received a number of photos from Pinnacles of A. incultorum, so that species definitely grows here, but I do not think this fits that very well (thickened stipe base, for example). I did not taste the mushroom.

results.notes:
Caloplaca Lichens

I can safely eliminate:
Albovariegata- bluish gray thallus, black apothecia
Atroflava- dark gray/brown thallus
Bolacina- yellow apothecia rims, thallus scattered, yellow squamules without the elongate marginal lobes this specimen has
Cerina- gray-rimmed, on trees
Citrina- like candelariella
Chrysophthalma- no elongated lobes, very disorganized
Coralloides- clustered, like xanthoria candelaria
Demissa- olive/gray/brown thallus, on cliffs
Epithallina- parasitic
Ferruginea- on trees
Flavorubescens- on trees, no lobes
Ludificans- thallus with little structure, grayish or yellowish and without the marginal lobes,
Luteominia- apothecia deep red, also without elongated colored margin
Nashii- no elongated lobes
Oregona- on trees
Persimilis- no lobes, on wood
Pyracea/ holocarpa sensu CA- on trees, looks like crenulata
Squamosa- as subsoluta, below
Stanfordensis- on trees
Stantonii- bicolored, margin without long distinct lobes
Subsoluta- thallus crowded and somewhat disorganized in shape, lacks elongated love tips
Variabilis- blackish apothecia, quite different

Can probably eliminate:
Decipiens- pruinose yellow\gold, apothecia very sparse, yellow soralia
Ignea- very red orange, apothecia concentrated at center
Stellata- apothecia sparse, star shaped lobes
Trachyphylla- surface rough\verruculose

Realistically, this leaves C. Saxicola and C. Impolita, assuming this is not X. Elegans

results.notes:
Found it on five redwood cones close to each other (a few meters at most), not on other debris, always shallowly buried in the duff, not exposed. There were a few mushrooms on the same cone and numerous primordia. The caps were very small, 2mm or less.

Microscopy all matches. Spores non-amyloid, about 7×4, trama (pileal and stipital) dextrinoid, basidia 13×9, cheilocystidia 25-30 × 7-11.

Thallus white, crustose, continuous to often rimose, K+Y, C-. Apothecia black, lecideine, carbonized, lightly pruinose. Hymenium hyaline, turning yellow to red in Lugol’s, with the uppermost layer turning blue (paraphyses tips?). Hypothecium dark brown. Epihymenium dark in thicker sections, yellow-brown in thin sections.

Spores 8/ascus, hyaline, narrowly ellipsoid, slightly curved, mostly 3-septate but septations often difficult to see. Average 23.8×5.7 (n=3).

Thallus continuous, areolate, off-white, K+? (might just be burning through cortex to aglae), C-. Apothecia black, lightly pruinose, biatorine, plane with a rim when young becoming convex without thalline margin. Hymenium hyaline, I+blue, hypothecium hyaline I+violet, epihymenium black.

Spores presumably 8/ascus, hyaline, ellipsoid, 1-septate. Average 13.5×4.6 (n=4).

I still have some work to do on this one, I assumed Buellia by the look of it, but spores are hyaline. Interesting set of micro features with the soft biatorine apothecia and hyaline hypothecium. Spores are a hair large for Catillaria nigroclavata, and photo’s online don’t look right.

I found a single specimen of this once before in Big Basin (Observation 197630).

Trichophaea species discussed in “Ascomycete fungi of North America” all seem to significantly differ, either in the specialized habitat, frb size, or spore size.

results.notes:
Dry conditions have caused these to crimp and shrivel a bit around the margins, but the genus is still unmistakable. Porodisculus was considered monotypic, consisting solely of P. pendulus, until Lee & Jung showed a cryptic, East Asian species to be morphologically and phylogentically distinct. They named it P. orientalis. According to the authors, all western hemisphere material corresponds to P. pendulus, with material from (at least) Japan and Korea corresponding to their sp. nov. One wonders to what extent Malagasy, European and Australasian collections represent new spp. or fall into one of the existing taxa, as collections from these regions did not form a part of Lee & Jung’s study.

results.notes:
Tricholoma album (Schaeff.) P. Kumm., Tricholomataceae, Agaricales. (Local name: Рядовка белая).
Whitish and very common mushroom with a convex smooth cap and close gills
Cap: 5-10cm wide, white or whitish up to brownish-white or yellowish-white, smooth, convex up to broadly convex, sometimes with a broad knob or indistinct knob, margin curved in when young, later it curved down or horizontal with a wide knob. Flesh is white; odour is unpleasant as a bad soap.
Gills: attached with narrowing toward stalk, close, narrow up to moderately broad when old, whitish up to light cream, sometimes pinkish when old.
Stalk: 6-12cm long, 1-2.5cm thick, usually enlarged toward base sometimes indistinct bulbous when old, whitish or light cream, somewhat cottony when young.
Habitat: small groups minor abundant scattered in mixed forest with pine-tree birches, sometimes they grow by two inside group.
Edibility: published that poisonous.
Season: July-August.

Irregular ‘ragged’ margin.
Pore surface. Irregular, elongated, maze-like pores.

results.notes:
This and my following observations of Graphis spp. are related with the material collected during 2014 and beginning of 2015 that served as a basis for the paper in Ref. 4. That paper reported seven species new to Europe of Graphis spp. already known from other parts of the world. As a beginner in the subject, I’m deeply grateful to my co-author in that paper – André Aptroot – a true expert in the genus Graphis, and of several other genera in lichens.
The material from the microscopy accompanying each observation is from my initial observations of the specimens and not from the subsequent analysis made by André to which every specimen was subjected. I will start posting at least one observation for each species reported as new to Europe in that paper and maybe in the future I will have opportunity to post some other observation made by that time and not further developed and thus not considered in the paper.
This paper was motivated by my refuse to accept that what I was observing in the field should be named as one of the very few species known to Europe at the time, a number that does not exceeded that of the fingers of a hand. It is my conviction that, even with the inclusion of the number of species in the afore mentioned article, that number is still far from translating the reality of the diversity of representation of that genus in my country.
The main reference for the study of Graphis is Ref. 1 – “A world-wide key to the genus Graphis” by Lucking, Archer & Aptroot; it was published together with Ref. 2 – “The taxonomy of the genus Graphis sensu Staiger” by Lucking, where the concepts used in the key are introduced and developed; two of the authors of Ref. 1 also participated in Ref. 3 – “A first assessment of the Ticolichen Biodiversity Inventory in Costa Rica”, where many species are described and some groups of species with similar features are mentioned.
Each observation will contain the following set of characters:
SPECIES: (details to reach the name are given below)
DATE: yyyy/mm/dd
SPECIMEN Nº:
PLACE:
HABITAT:
SUBSTRATE:
MICRO FEATURES:

  • Striation: (levels: Entire / Striate)
  • Carbonization: (levels: Apical / Lateral / Complete)
  • Inspersion: (levels: Clear / Inspersed)
  • Ascospores: (levels: Transverse / Muriform) – Size (levels: small / medium / large)
    • GROUP No.: (as defined in Ref. 1 of this observation)

CHEMISTRY:
ASCOSPORES DIMENSIONS:
EVOLUTION IN THE KEY: (according Ref. 1 of this observation)
INTERNAL LINKS: (MO observations, if existing)
EXTERNAL LINKS: (with illustrations of the species)

As in other cases, and contrary to other authors, we consider these to represent distinct species, but the available material is sparse and the variation in excipulum carbonization cannot be properly assessed at this point.
